description:
Anaerococcus groningensis is a species of anaerobic, Gram-positive, coccoid-shaped bacterium. It was first isolated from a clinical sample obtained from a human patient in Groningen, the Netherlands, hence the specific epithet "groningensis."

This bacterium is a member of the genus Anaerococcus, which are known to be part of the normal human microbiome, particularly in the urogenital and gastrointestinal tracts. Anaerococcus groningensis is an obligate anaerobe, meaning it can only grow and thrive in the absence of oxygen.

Morphologically, Anaerococcus groningensis cells are typically non-spore-forming and non-motile cocci, with a diameter ranging from 0.5 to 1.0 micrometers. The bacterium is catalase-positive and exhibits fermentative metabolism, producing various end products such as acetic acid and lactic acid.

Genetically, Anaerococcus groningensis is closely related to other species within the Anaerococcus genus, but it can be distinguished from them based on its unique 16S rRNA gene sequence and other phenotypic characteristics. Further research is ongoing to better understand the ecological role and potential clinical significance of this anaerobic bacterium.
prompt: Provide a short scientific description of this species: Anaerococcus groningensis
